Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Personalized recommender systems based on semantical clustering
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to build a recommender system which assigns values to artifacts and will also provide stakeholders in unregulated markets with better information for reducing risk and improving trust. The Internet and technology have entirely changed the nature of interactions between every business sector, including the art industry, by creating a digital marketplace and introducing additional issues for markets regulation. The proposed recommender system can be used to predict value of investment, to provide an objective value of goods in legal proceedings, insurance cases, and banks as a collateral toll. This supports financial stability of markets through better decision making and improves the trust of stakeholders in their investments. It also helps to maintain control of the commercial aspects of work. For example, the acquisitions departments of museums would be served by knowing a real value for the artifacts they buy.

This I-Corps project is focused on building a recommender system for assigning values to artworks using existing datasets and deep knowledge. Art markets are often misvalued which makes the classical approach to building recommender systems rather difficult due to unreliable datasets. Classifiers trained on these datasets often assign inflated prices. A crowd approach is used here which is expected to give more reliable results. Personalization for this class of problems can be achieved by assigning semantic distance. The project extends the group of classical features by adding semantic features from mining comments given by users, and, for example, from artist biographies, and images of paintings. For each cluster of semantically similar artists, a personalized recommender system for art evaluation is built. Wisdom of the crowd will be used to assign a specific value to an art piece.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first goal of the project was the creation of a software system designed to help stakeholders in the art market understand the value of the art objects (currently paintings) and help them to make better decisions regarding investments into works of art, to make better returns on investment and develop a new business model for the art market, which helps to increase the number of new customers and mitigate market risk. Currently, the art market does not have a trustable methodology in evaluation. 

Its development required construction of multiple datasets describing artworks and artists, construction of new multimedia features, text features, and classifiers used to build a recommender system engine.  For that purpose, we built Artwork Data Dump (Paintings Dataset and Artists Dataset) which includes quite detailed information about more than 220,000 artworks and over 3,000 artists from 70+ countries collected from the data available on the web. The current precision of our recommender system in assigning price tags to artworks is 68.5% and its recall is 69%.

The second goal of the project was the validation of the system in the commercial art market.  To validate our system, we conducted 175+ interviews with interested shareholders in the art market and learned about their specific pain points.  This information was used to guide the development of our software to better address the needs of future users.  Finally, we had to develop an understanding of the complex landscape of the contemporary art market.  This required acquiring partnerships and developing strategies for pricing and product deployment. 

The interviews also helped us to specify our customer segments. These include emerging and established artists, auction house specialists, gallery directors, art dealers and art collectors. Our interviews led us to explore the type of customer relationships that are based on referrals, loyalty programs, and community development.
